data.title: John Steinbeck
data.meta_description: News about John Steinbeck, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Arts and Letters

Where Have All the Artist-Addicts Gone?

For much of the 20th century, before the dawn of our own wellness-focused era, madness and substance abuse were often considered prerequisites for great art.

By M. H. Miller and Duane Michals

Writer’s Best Friend

On National Pet Day, we look at some of our most famous authors and the furry companions — dogs, cats and even goats — who offered them inspiration.

By Alexandra Alter and Erica Ackerberg

exclusive

John Steinbeck’s ‘Little Fishing Place’ in Sag Harbor Is on the Market

The novelist spent his summers at the waterfront property, which sits on 1.8 acres and includes his “writing house.” The asking price is $17.9 million.

By Vivian Marino

Nonfiction

John Steinbeck, Bard of the American Worker

In a new biography, “Mad at the World,” William Souder claims the “Of Mice and Men” author was motivated by anger toward injustice.

By Brenda Wineapple

Frank Sinatra Slept Here, and So Can You

In New York and across the country, the former homes of famous writers, musicians and film stars are available as short-term rentals.

By Caroline Biggs

Live Like a Star

Short-term rentals around the country offer connections to the rich and famous, including the likes of Frank Sinatra, Bob Dylan and Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.

Unearthed Steinbeck Short Story Isn’t at All Like ‘Grapes of Wrath’

The quintessentially American author wrote pieces for a Paris newspaper in the 1950s. Now, one of those — about a nervous chef and a magnificent cat — is being published in English for the first time.

By Jacey Fortin
